tn.text: The story shifts back to Saul and his salvation.
These verses give background information telling us what Saul has been doing since the stoning of Stephen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Here the word "him" refers to the high priest and "he" refers to Saul.

tn.ref: still speaking threats even of murder against the disciples
tn.text: The noun "murder" can be translated as a verb. AT: "still speaking threats, even to murder the disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This refers to the people in the synagogues. AT: "for the people in the synagogues" or "for the leaders in the synagogues" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"when he found anyone" or "if he found anyone"
"who followed the teachings of Jesus Christ"
This term appears to have been a title for Christianity at that time.

tn.ref: he might bring them bound to Jerusalem
tn.text: "he might take them as prisoners to Jerusalem." Paul's purpose can be made clear by adding "so that the Jewish leaders could judge and punish them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
After the high priest gave Saul the letters, Saul left for Damascus.
Saul left Jerusalem and now travels to Damascus.
This is an expression that marks a change in the story to show something different is about to happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

tn.ref: there shone all around him a light out of heaven
tn.text: "a light from heaven shone all around him"
Possible meanings are 1) heaven, where God lives or 2) the sky. The first meaning is preferable. Use that meaning if your language has a separate word for it.

Possible meanings are that 1) "Saul threw himself to the ground" or 2) "The light caused him to fall to the ground" or 3) "Saul fell to the ground the way one who fainted fell." Saul did not fall accidentally.

This rhetorical question communicates a rebuke to Saul. In some languages a statement would be more natural (AT): "You are persecuting me!" or a command (AT): "Stop persecuting me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Every occurrence of the word "you" here is singular.
Saul was not acknowledging that Jesus is the Lord. He uses that title because he understood that he spoke to someone of supernatural power.

tn.ref: but rise, enter into the city
tn.text: "get up and go into the city Damascus"
This can be stated in the active form. AT: "someone will tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: hearing the voice, but seeing no one
tn.text: "they heard the voice, but they did not see anyone"
"but saw no one." Apparently only Saul experienced the light.
This implies that he had closed his eyes because the light was too bright. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"he could not see anything." Saul was blind.
"was blind" or "could not see anything" (UDB)
It is not stated whether he chose not to eat or drink as a form of worship, or if he had no appetite because he was too distressed from his situation. It is preferable not to specify the reason.

The story of Saul continues but Luke introduces another man named Ananias. This is not the same Ananias who died earlier in Acts  [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:03|5:3]]. You may translate it the same way though as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:01|5:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Though there is more than one  Judas mentioned in the New Testament, it is likely this is the only appearance of this Judas.
This introduces Ananias as a new character. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
"And Ananias said"

tn.ref: go to the street which is called Straight
tn.text: "go to Straight Street" (UDB)
This Judas is not the disciple who betrayed Jesus. This Judas was owner of a house in Damascus where Saul was staying.

tn.ref: a man from Tarsus named Saul
tn.text: "a man from the city of Tarsus named Saul" or "Saul of Tarsus"
This was a symbol of giving a spiritual blessing to Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"be able to see again"
Here "holy people" refers to Christians. AT: "the people in Jerusalem who believe in you" (UDB)
It is implied that the extent of the power and authority granted Saul was limited to the Jewish people at this point in time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "your name" refers to Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he is a chosen instrument of mine
tn.text: "chosen instrument" refers to something that is set apart for service. AT: "I have chosen him to serve me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an expression for identifying or speaking out for Jesus. AT: "in order that he might speak about me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: for the cause of my name
tn.text: This is an expression meaning "for telling people about me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Ananias goes to the house where Saul is staying. After Saul is healed, the story shifts from Ananias back to Saul.
The word "you" here is singular and refers to Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:workbench:translate:formsofyou-singular]])

tn.ref: So Ananias departed, and entered into the house
tn.text: It may be helpful to state that Ananias went to the house before he entered into it. AT: "So Ananias went, and after he found the house where Saul was, he entered it" (UDB)
Ananias put his hands on Saul. This was a symbol of giving a blessing to Saul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: so that you might receive your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "has sent me so that you might see again and that the Holy Spirit might fill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"something that appeared like fish scales fell"
"he was able to see again"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he got up and Ananias baptized him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here only the second "he" refers to Jesus, the Son of God. The first "he" and the other ones refer to Saul.
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is a hyperbole for "Many who heard." If you express exaggeration differently, then use your form. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Is not this the man who destroyed those in Jerusalem who called on this name?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical and negative question that emphasizes that Saul was indeed the man who had persecuted the believers. AT: "This is the man who destroyed those in Jerusalem who called on this name Jesus!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "name" refers to Jesus. AT: "the name of Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
They were distressed in the sense that they could not find a way to refute Saul's arguments that Jesus was the Christ.
The word "him" in this section refers to Saul.
This refers to the leaders of the Jews. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: But their plan became known to Saul
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But someone told their plan to Saul" or "But Saul learned about their plan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This city had a wall surrounding it. People could normally only enter and exit the city through the gates.
people who believed Saul's message about Jesus and were following his teaching

tn.ref: let him down through the wall, lowering him in a basket
tn.text: "used ropes to lower him in a large basket through an opening in the wall" (UDB)
Here the words "he" and "him" refer to Saul all but one time. "And 'he' told them how" in verse 27 refers to Barnabas.

tn.ref: but they were all afraid of him
tn.text: "They were all" is an exaggeration for many or most of them. AT: "almost all of them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: boldly preached in the name of Jesus
tn.text: This is a way of saying he preached or taught the gospel message of Jesus Christ without fear. AT: "openly preached the message about Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "them" refers to Jewish people and people who had converted to Judaism.

tn.ref: in the name of the Lord Jesus
tn.text: Here "name" is a metonym for the gospel message of Jesus Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Saul tried to reason with the Jews who spoke Greek.
The words "the brothers" refers to the believers in Jerusalem.
The phrase "brought him down" is used here because Caesarea is lower in elevation than Jerusalem.
Caesarea was a seaport. They brothers probably sent Saul to Tarsus by ship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
In verse 32, the story shifts from Saul to a new part of the story about Peter.
Verse 31 is a statement that gives an update on the church's growth.

tn.ref: the church throughout all Judea, Galilee, and Samaria
tn.text: This is the first use of the singular "church" to refer to more than one local congregation. Here it refers to all the believers in all the groups throughout Israel.
"lived peacefully" (UDB). This means the persecution that started with the murder of Stephen was finished.
The agent was either God or the Holy Spirit. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God helped them grow" or "the Holy Spirit built them up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: walking in the fear of the Lord
tn.text: "continuing to honor the Lord"

tn.ref: in the comfort of the Holy Spirit
tn.text: "with the Holy Spirit strengthening and encouraging them"
This phrase is used to mark a new part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
This is an exaggeration for Peter's visiting many of the believers throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
The phrase "came down" is used here because Lydda is lower in elevation than the other places where he was traveling.
Lydda is a city located about 18 kilometers southeast of Joppa. This city was called Lod in the Old Testament and in modern Israel.

tn.ref: There he found a certain man
tn.text: Peter was not intentionally searching for a paralyzed person, but happened upon him. AT: "There Peter met a man"
This introduces Aeneas as a new character in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: who had been in his bed ... was paralyzed
tn.text: This is background information about Aeneas. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
unable to walk, probably unable to move below the waist
"roll up your mat" (UDB)
This is a hyperbole meaning "many people who lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
The city of Lydda was located in the Plain of Sharon.
It may be helpful to state that they saw that he was healed. AT: "saw the man whom Peter had healed"
Luke continues the story with a new event about Peter.
These verses give background information about the woman named Tabitha. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This introduces a new part in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])

Tabitha is her name in the Aramaic language, and Dorcas is her name in the Greek language. Both names mean "gazelle." AT: "Her name in the Greek language was Dorcas" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"doing many good things"

tn.ref: It came about in those days
tn.text: This refers to the time when Peter was in Joppa. This can be stated. AT: "It came about while Peter was nearby" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This was washing to prepare for her burial.

tn.ref: they laid her in an upper room
tn.text: This was a temporary display of the body during the funeral process.

tn.ref: they sent two men to him
tn.text: "the disciples sent two men to Peter"
"to the upstairs room where Dorcas' body was lying" (UDB)
It is possible that all the widows of the town were there since it was not a large town.
women whose husbands had died and therefore needed help

tn.ref: while she had been with them
tn.text: "while she was still alive with the disciples" (UDB)
The story of Tabitha ends in verse 42. Verse 43 tells us what happens to Peter after the story ends. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])

tn.ref: put them all out of the room
tn.text: "told them all to leave the room." Peter had everyone leave so he could be alone to pray for Tabitha.

tn.ref: gave her his hand and lifted her up
tn.text: Peter took hold of her hand and helped her stand up.
The widows were possibly also believers but are mentioned specifically because Tabitha was so important to them.

tn.ref: This matter became known throughout all Joppa
tn.text: This refers to the miracle of Peter's raising Tabitha from the dead. It can be stated in active form. AT: "People throughout all Joppa heard about this matter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"believed in the gospel of the Lord Jesus"
"It came about that." This introduces the beginning of the next event in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"a man named Simon who made leather from animal skins" (UDB)
